text: A million suns shine in the dark. A STARSHIP cuts through the night: a gleaming white cruis Galleries of windows. Flying decks and observation domes. On the hull: EXCELSIOR - A HomeStead Company Starship. The ship flashes through a nebula. Space-dust sparkles as whips over the hull, betraying the ship's dizzying speed. The nebula boils in the ship's wake. The Excelsior rocket on, spotless and beautiful as a daydream.

A wide plaza. Its lofty atrium cuts through seven decks, creating tiers of promenades framing a vast skylight. The promenades are empty. Chairs unoccupied. Beetle-like robots vacuum the carpets and wax the floors.
Super-modern and gleaming. Hundreds of tables, all empty.
Lounge furniture and star-filled windows. Completely deserted. A robot on spindly legs washes the glass.

Endless corridors lined with vertical glass tubes. Inside each tube stands a PASSENGER. Eyes closed in sleep. If they're breathing you can't tell by looking. They sleep on their feet, leaning against padded supports Straps secure them in place; sensors adhere to their skin They wear shorts and tank tops with HomeStead Company log We survey their faces. No children, no senior citizens. M and women of every ethnicity in the prime of their lives. We settle on one man. JIM PRESTON, 38. Sound asleep. A sm display on his pod reads:
Rate 2 Mechanical Engineer Denver, Colorado
Blood type: A+ Passenger class: silver

A deep BOOM. Echoes roll down the corridors. Lights wink on in Jim's hibernation pod. Machinery hums t life. Instruments beep and chitter. Medical data fills the pod's screen. Jim's temperature ri His heart begins to beat. He takes a breath. Jim opens his eyes. Groggy, blinking, seeing nothing. The backrest behind him converts into a recliner, lowerin him into a seated position. The sensors on his skin drop off and snake back into the pod's machinery. A video screen descends before Jim's eyes. ONSCREEN - A beautiful stewardess appears, beaming at the camera. She is inhumanly perfect, a computer-generated im
Good Morning, James!
Jim. What the...
Don't worry, Jim. It's normal to feel confused. You've just spent a hundred and twenty years in suspended animation.
She makes it sound sexy. Jim scowls and rubs his eyes. ONSCREEN - An animation. Happy people go to sleep in glas tubes in a hospital. The tubes are loaded onto a spaceshi

You're a passenger on the Starship Excelsior - a Homestead Company Starship. We've nearly completed the 120-year flight from Earth to your new home - the colony world of Homestead II. Congratulations!
ONSCREEN - The Excelsior leaves a skyscraper-covered Eart and soars through space to a lush green Homestead II.
Oh, yeah.
The Excelsior is on final approach.
For the next two months, you'll enjoy luxury space travel. Food. Fun. New friends.
ONSCREEN - The ship's lavish amenities: fine dining, spor facilities, shops, all swarming with happy passengers.
Then you'll start your new life on Homestead II. Back to basics. A fresh start. Room to grow.
ONSCREEN - Publicity shots of Homestead II. Mountains, forests, beaches. Settlements ringed by farmland.
Your wake-up capsules and nutrient juice will help you recover from hibernation!

Pills rattle into a dish; a glass of pink juice appears. takes his pills and gulps his juice with a grimace. Jim's backrest eases him onto his feet. A drawer pops ope revealing a Homestead Company bathrobe and slippers.
Make yourself comfortable in your complimentary robe and slippers.
He puts them on.
Your shipcard is your key to the starship.
Don't lose it!
The pod produces Jim's shipcard: a plastic ID card on a lanyard. He hangs it around his neck.
Now you're ready to go to your cabin. Make yourself at home! Enjoy the rest of your voyage, Jim!
Right.
Jim steps out of his pod into the corridor. All the other pods are closed, the people inside asleep. look of concern crosses Jim's face.
Jim, your cabin is this way.
The screen flips around to face him. The video stewardess points down the corridor.
Take Elevator D to deck seven. Your cabin number is on your shipcard.
Thanks.
He shuffles down the corridor in his slippers, rubbing hi face. Having trouble keeping his eyes open. Behind him, his pod closes up. Its screen reads PASSENGER DISCHARGED.  ELEVATOR FOYER
Jim finds a bank of elevators. As he approaches, the indicators blink on. An elevator opens, spilling light. He steps inside, and muzak begins to play.  DECK SEVEN
A corridor lined with doors. A CLEANING ROBOT vacuums. Jim appears. Instantly the corridor lights brighten. The cleaning robot rolls past Jim.
Hello, Passenger.
Hello, robot.
Jim follows wall markings to his cabin. Lets himself in.  JIM'S CABIN
Cozy but small. A bed, a desk, an armchair. No window. A SCREEN lights up. The HomeStead Company theme music pla An ANNOUNCER speaks.
Welcome to your cabin, Jim! Your home until we make landfall.
Jim doesn't pay attention. Pokes around, opening drawers.
Over the next two months, you'll prepare for your new life on Homestead II.
Jim peers into the tiny bathroom. There's a little video screen, and the presentation's running there too.
Passengers are organized into Learning Groups for orientation. You've been assigned to Learning group...thirty-eight! Don't forget!

ONSCREEN: "Learning Group 38." The DOORBELL rings. Jim opens the door eagerly - and deflates. No one there. He looks down. A waist-high CARGO ROBOT peers up at him w goggle eyes. It carries two suitcases and a duffel bag.
Passenger James Preston?
Jim. Yeah.
Your luggage, Passenger Jim. Swipe your shipcard to confirm.
Jim swipes his shipcard through a slot on top of the robo The robot scoots inside and deposits Jim's bags on the fl
Enjoy your luggage!
Thanks.
Thank you, Passenger Jim!
The robot zips out the door. Jim looks up and down the corridor. The receding robot is only sign of life. He steps back inside.
Your group's orientation starts in forty-five minutes. Join them in Conference Room Twenty on Deck One. Don't forget!
A mall with tiled floors and ornate storefronts. Jim walks along in his robe and slippers. Storefront sign flicker to life as he passes. A dry fountain gushes water at his approach.

Forty chairs around a big table. A large screen on the wa ONSCREEN: A digital INSTRUCTOR, a handsome woman of middl age, waits with a computer's infinite patience. Jim walks in. The door slides closed behind him.
Hello, Passengers. Will you all please take a seat.
Jim looks around. He's the only one there. He sits.
Earth is a prosperous planet. The cradle of civilization. A world with a long, proud history. But for many, it's also overpopulated. Over-priced. Overrated. Overrun.
Behind the Instructor, video clips of Earth's urban spraw an endless gleaming metropolis glittering with traffic.
(raising his hand) Can I just...
No questions until the end, please.
Wait. Where are all the other...
The Colonies offer an alternative. A better way of life.
The screen fills with shots of Homestead II: aerial foota of mountains, beaches, beautiful garden cities.
And none is more beautiful than Homestead II, the Jewel of the Occupied Worlds.
Jim sits wearily, chin propped on his hand. The Video Instructor chatters on. Inspiring footage of Homestead II

...thriving job markets in mining, farming and manufacturing. An explosion in the cultural arts. And if you long for the life less civilized, you can apply for a pioneer permit and seek your fortune in the wild. (a pregnant pause) Any questions?
Where IS everybody?!
The Instructor pauses. The question seems to confuse her.
We're all on the Starship Excelsior. Five thousand passengers and fifty- eight crew members.
But I'm the only one awake.
No, all the passengers wake up at the same time.
Then something's wrong with the other hibernation pods.
Hibernation pods are fail-safe.
So why am I the only one here?
I'm sorry. I don't understand your question.
GRAND CONCOURSE
Jim finds an INFOMAT - an information kiosk. A banner scr across the screen: ASK ME A QUESTION! Jim taps the screen
Hello! What's your question?
I need to talk to a person. A real live person.
What sort of person? Personal trainer? Travel planner? Therapist?
Someone in charge.
The Ship Steward handles passenger affairs. You can find him in his office on the Service Deck.
ONSCREEN: A dotted line on the map shows how to get there
Thank you.
Happy to help!
Jim appears around the corner. The lights brighten, the ventilation kicks up a notch. He finds a door marked SHIP STEWARD.
The lights flash on as Jim enters, revealing...an office mothballs. Empty chairs, barren desks.
Not good.  ELEVATOR LOBBY
Another Infomat. Jim arrives at a jog.
Hello! What's your quest...
Who's flying the ship?
The bridge crew includes the Captain, the Pilot, the Chief Navigator...
The Captain. I want to talk to the Captain.
The Captain rarely handles passenger queries directly.
Emergency, okay? Where is he?
The Captain is usually found on the Bridge, on the Command Deck.
ONSCREEN: A helpful map shows the way. Jim marches off.  COMMAND DECK

Jim finds the door to the Bridge. He opens it eagerly - o to find a second door behind it - an armored hatch labele FIREWALL and SECURE ACCESS AREA. A porthole of thick glass gives a narrow view of the Brid It's deserted. Instrument lights gleam in the dark.
(pounding on the hatch) Come on! What the hell is happening?
Jim RUNS past restaurants, lounges, shops. All deserted.
(panic in his voice) Hello? Hello!
The highest promenade on the ship: windows on all sides. huge skylight just overhead. It's almost like being outsi The atrium plunges seven stories to the Concourse below.
(an echoing shout) Hello!

A SOUND behind him makes him spin. But it's just a window-washer: a robot with long spindly limbs. It moves past Jim, polishing windows. Oblivious. A sign catches Jim's attention: "OBSERVATORY - Your Place the Universe."  OBSERVATORY

Jim enters the planetarium of the future: theater seats facing a holographic "stage." IN HOLOGRAM: An image of the starship hangs in space. Glo text reads "Look through the eyes of the Starship Excelsi Jim goes to the control podium. Touches the screen.
(a voice as deep as God's) What can I show you?
We're supposed to land pretty soon, but it looks like I'm the only one awake. Is that normal?
I don't understand. What can I show you?
Show me Homestead II.
IN HOLOGRAM: The planet Homestead II, Earth's twin sister
Homestead II is the fourth planet in the Bhakti system.
Right. And how soon are we landing?
Approximately ninety years.
What?
We land on Homestead II in ninety years, three weeks, and one day.
No. How long ago did we leave Earth?
Approximately thirty years ago.
Jim stares at the hologram in horrified realization.
I woke up too soon.
I don't understand.
Neither do I.  HIBERNATION BAY

Jim sprints down a row of hibernation pods. Heart poundin Slides to a stop in front of his empty pod. Jim fusses with the controls, pressing buttons. But the screen just reads "PASSENGER DISCHARGED." Crouching, he pulls at the pod's canopy, trying to open i with his hands. It doesn't budge.
I'm supposed to be in there!

Jim trudges between rows of sleeping passengers to the af end of the huge Hibernation Bay. There he finds a hatch labeled CREW HIBERNATION FACILITY. Jim opens it eagerly - and finds another armored hatch wi small porthole. Labels reads FIREWALL and SECURE ACCESS A Jim presses the switch. No result. He peers through the porthole. Inside, the entire crew of starship stands sleeping.
Jim stands at another Infomat.
How do I make a phone call?
Your cabin telephone...
No. Long distance. How do I send a message to Earth?
Interstellar messages are sent by laser array. Speak to the Duty Officer in the Comm Center.
ONSCREEN: The Infomat displays a helpful map.
Please note that interstellar messaging is an expensive service.
Bite me.
Happy to help!
Two communications booths for passenger use. Jim sits at of these. Swipes his shipcard.
Planet and connection?
Earth. The HomeStead Company.
There are thirty thousand phone numbers listed under "HomeStead Company." What number?
I don't know. I'm emigrating to Homestead II. I have an emergency.
Division of Colonial Affairs, Homestead II Program. I have a Customer Help Line.
Sounds about right.
The booth's camera zooms in on Jim's face. A microphone extends toward his mouth. The red RECORDING light comes o
Begin message.
Jim's a deer in the headlights. He collects himself.

Hi. I'm Jim Preston. I'm a passenger on the Excelsior. Something went wrong with my hibernation pod and I woke up too soon. Ninety years too soon. I can't get back to sleep. Nobody else is awake. (with growing panic) If I don't figure something out, I'm going to die of old age before we get to Homestead II. So help me out here. (takes a deep breath) I'll keep trying to fix this. Maybe I missed something simple. But I could use a hand. Thanks.
Jim pushes the "SEND" button. Sits back in his chair.
Message sent.
Outstanding.
Message will arrive in nineteen years.
Say what?
Earliest possible reply in fifty-five years.
No.
We are nineteen light years from Earth. By the time your message arrives, we will be thirty-six light- years from Earth. We apologize for the delay.
Fifty-five years.
That will be six thousand dollars.  GRAND CONCOURSE

Jim crosses the Concourse like a sleepwalker in his robe slippers. He looks shell-shocked. He comes to the Concourse Bar: the fanciest watering hole the ship. Black leather stools along a marble bartop. Jim touches the bartop...and a MAN swings up behind the b as if mounted on a hinge. A handsome fellow in a bartende uniform - his hair and skin eerily perfect. This is ARTHU Jim jumps out of his skin.
What can I get you?
I thought I was the only one awake!
I doubt it. It's the middle of the afternoon. Are you drinking or not?

He produces a cloth and polishes the bartop. In a startli movement, he glides the length of the bar, polishing all way, and glides back as if on roller skates. Jim steps up on the footrail and peers behind the bar. Arthur's body stops at the waist. He's mounted on rails, built into the bar.
You're a robot.
Android, technically. Arthur's the name.
(taking a seat) I'm Jim.
Arthur shakes his hand.
Pleased to meet you. What'll it be?
Whiskey, neat.
Arthur pours. Jim knocks the drink back. Points into the empty glass while his eyes water. Arthur pours another. J takes a big swallow and sets the glass down half-full.
Arthur, how much do you know about the ship?
I don't know. I know some things.
What do I do if my hibernation pod malfunctions?
Impossible. Hibernation pods are fail- safe.
Yeah, well, I woke up early.
Can't happen.
How long until we get to Homestead II?
Ninety years or so.
And when are all of us passengers supposed to wake up?
Not until the last two months.
So how can I be sitting here with ninety years to go?
Arthur's eyes take on a faraway look. His head twitches.
It's not possible for you to be here.
He smiles as if he's solved the problem.
But I am.
Sorry, Jim. My specialty is cocktails and conversation. Take your fancy trick questions to one of those Infomats. They think they know everything.
Arthur, I'm in trouble. I'm screwed. I am completely, ridiculously screwed.
Lot of self-pity.
Self pity? I'm going to die of old age on this ship!
Jim, we all die. Even androids end up on the scrap heap. It's not dying that matters, it's living. This is your life. Are you going to live it or lie down and die?
Jim shakes his head in surrender.
What do I owe you?
Jim, the booze is on the house.
A moody lounge with panoramic windows. Jim walks in. Stro up to the glass. Stares out at the red stars behind the ship, the cold whi stars all around.
Jim wakes up and rolls out of bed. Shuffles into the show  CAFETERIA
Machines offer food and drink in dizzying variety. Each machine has a card slot and a screen displaying its menu. Jim enters, dressed in his own clothes - jeans, a T-shirt
He swipes his shipcard at a coffee machine. It offers six kinds of coffee, from a simple cup of joe to the "Mocha Cappuccino Extreme." Jim picks the best of the lot.
Sorry. The Mocha Cappuccino Extreme is reserved for gold-class passengers. Please select another item.
Jim presses one button after another, denied each time.
Sorry...sorry...sorry...Large coffee.
Are you serious?
Please enjoy.  ELEVATOR
Jim ascends, sipping coffee and eating an egg sandwich. The doors open at the Command Deck. A sign reads "Crew Ar No Passengers beyond this point." Jim breezes past the si  COMMAND DECK

Jim prowls the floor, opening doors. He finds a room marked EMERGENCY GEAR and opens it eagerl It's full of space suits and oxygen tanks. He peers into a red HAZARD cabinet: fire extinguishers, a axe, an epoxy foamer for atmosphere leaks - all behind gl He opens another door marked EMERGENCY MANUALS - and smil shelf after shelf of waterproof, fireproof technical manu Jim pulls a manual labeled HIBERNATION SYSTEMS.
A cavernous cargo hold. Jim drives a forklift down the ai scanning container numbers. He finds a container labeled "PASSENGER #1498, JAMES PRESTON." The forklift pulls it from the rack.
Opens to reveal Jim's belongings. Cartons marked "sports" "clothes" or "kitchen stuff." Amidst the cartons, a heavy-duty TOOLBOX. Jim hauls it ou  HIBERNATION BAY

Jim sits in front of his empty hibernation pod. His toolb beside him. The Hibernation Systems manual lies open. Jim tinkers with the electronics inside his pod. The pod hums to life. Its data screen flickers with information. Mysterious WHIRS and THUNKS. The canopy opens. Elated, Jim bounces to his feet. Strips off his shirt and scrambles in. The canopy closes over him. He assumes the position, his back against the backrest, waiting for the pod to put him to sleep. Nothing happens. He pokes at the ports where the sensors intravenous lines used to protrude. Shakes the machine. He gives up. It's not working. But now he's trapped inside the pod. He pushes at the canopy, but it's locked shut. He pounds the glass with no effect. Finally he loses it, shouting a stamping, hammering and raging - all muffled behind glass Exhausted, he sinks to the floor of the pod, staring out his tools and his manual, his discarded shirt. Then he notices the emergency release handle down by the floor. He pulls it, and the canopy pops open.
The pod's display screen blinks back to its original mess PASSENGER DISCHARGED.
Jim looks through the porthole at the sleeping crew. Jim swipes his shipcard through the door switch. ACCESS DENIED. He pokes at the keypad. ACCESS DENIED.
Jim opens his toolbox, selects a tool and starts to remov the keypad's cover plate.

Jim works on the door with an industrial LASER CUTTER. Sp fly. He's drenched in sweat. Mussed and unshaven. He lifts the goggles and inspects the door. The laser cut has barely marked the surface. The door's a mess. Its switch hangs on wires. There are p marks around the latch. Gouges around the window. Failed drill holes. Dents left by an axe. But the door stands firm. Jim lets the laser cutter fall. It joins a scrapyard of t on the floor: sledgehammer, jackhammer, drill, crowbar, a
Another debris field surrounds Jim's hibernation pod. Too and cables, electronic instruments, a diagnostic laptop. Jim stalks by without so much as a sideways glance.
Arthur stands behind the bar polishing glasses. Jim sits, sweaty and grimy, a whiskey in front of him. His speech is soft around the edges. He's had a few.
I thought I'd figure something out. I thought it would just come to me.
Stands to reason.
But I've tried everything.
Sometimes you can't catch a break.
Jim gives Arthur a thoughtful look.
I'm your only customer, but you're always polishing a glass.
Trick of the trade. Makes people nervous when a bartender just stands there.
Okay. Lay some bartender wisdom on me. I'm lost in space here.
Arthur polishes the bar while he thinks that one over.
You're not where you want to be. You feel like you're supposed to be somewhere else. Right?
You said it.
Well, here's the thing. Say you could snap your fingers and be wherever you wanted to be. Back on Earth, or on Homestead II.
Okay.
I'll bet even if you got your wish, you'd still feel this way. Not in the right place. Supposed to be somewhere else. That's not a crisis, it's the human condition.
Jim takes a moment to consider that.
That's not me.
Well, maybe not. The point is, you can't get so wrapped up in where you'd rather be that you forget to make the most of where you are.
What are you telling me?
It's a big ship. You're always running around banging on things and yelling at the computers. Take a break. Live a little.
Jim spins on his barstool, surveying the Grand Concourse.
Live a little.
When he comes back around he gives a shove. He spins fast
That's the spirit.
Jim goes for one more shove. Misses. Falls off his stool.

Jim scans a map of the ship. Second-class cabins. First-c cabins. And the good stuff: palatial suites named for European cities. His finger stops on one of the biggest. The Berlin Suite.  BERLIN SUITE

High ceilings, posh furniture, panoramic windows. The door jumps in its frame with a THUNK. Slides open. Ji enters, a crowbar in hand. A cargo robot follows him in, carrying his toolbox and suitcases. It deposits them on the floor.
The Berlin Suite! Enjoy your luggage!
Jim cleans up in the opulent bathtub. A robot arm with a water jet washes his back.
Jim unpacks. Stowing clothes in closets, laying out memen He pulls a pair of sneakers out of his luggage.
Jim shoots baskets in sneakers and gym clothes. He's not He shoots, rebounds, shoots.  SPA
Jim lies on a massage table wearing a towel. A pair of ro arms emerge from the table and begin to massage him.
The Italian restaurant. Cafe tables, white tablecloths. Jim sits perusing a menu. A robotic waiter - a machine, n counterfeit human - rolls up to the table.
Let me have the rigatoni alla diabla, with the sauteed spinach and a glass of the Montepulciano.
A state-of-the-art game room. Jim inspects the flagship g "Z Factor!" A huge holographic display, a futuristic cock Jim swipes his shipcard. The game speaks like an angry gi
Jim Preston! Welcome to the cutting edge of gaming! The greatest challenge you will ever know!
All right then.
He clambers into the cockpit.
Are you ready to play Z Factor?
Yes!
(an echoing roar) Begin!
IN HOLOGRAM: A fortress shines on a hilltop. War machines crawl over a blasted land. Letters flash: LEVEL ONE.
A WARRIOR appears. Jim's character. Jim works the control IN HOLOGRAM: The Warrior rises off the ground on a beam o light - and is immediately torn to pieces by enemy fire.
You lose! Z Factor reigns supreme!
The game howls with demonic laughter.
A classic theater. Seats for a thousand. A velvet curtain Jim enters. Cued by his arrival, the curtain parts. The f begins. Jim settles into a seat.

Jim is playing "Z Factor!" and he's on fire. IN HOLOGRAM: The Warrior battles dragons above a crystall city. A title announces "Level 40." Jim moves like a martial artist, dripping sweat. IN HOLOGRAM: The Warrior challenges the game's Final Enem a colossus with a hundred eyes. The Final Enemy falls dea
You are victorious!
Yes!
You are the Grand Master of Z Factor!
I am the Grand Master of Z Factor!

Jim shoots baskets. He's brought dozens of balls onto the court. He no longer rebounds, just grabs the nearest ball He shoots from half court. From even farther away. Long shots, bounce shots off the wall.
He launches a full-court shot, bangs it off the rim, and himself topple over backward. Lies staring at the ceiling

The ship's Mexican restaurant. It has the same robot wait as the Italian place, but here they wear sombreros. Jim sits over the wreckage of his lunch. He downs a marga and puts the empty glass down beside several others.
Another margarita!
You have had many, senor.
Margarita otra vez!
Si, senor.
A room full of workstations, each with a reading machine. sits at one in a headset, taking a Russian Language cours
This is the Gudonov Russian Language Course. Level One. Let's begin. Repeat after me.
[I am beginning to learn.]
[I am beginning to learn.]
I am beginning to learn.
I am beginning to learn.
Jim sits drinking. Three glasses in front of him. Drunk.
(in bad Russian, subtitled) [I be study the Russian.]
(in perfect Russian, subtitled) [Good for you! It's a beautiful language.]
You speak Russian!
Of course. We have Russian passengers.
Well, I'm trying new things. From now on, every time I sit down, I want a drink I haven't had before.
Fair enough.
Arthur mixes a bright green drink, sets it in front of Ji Jim takes a sip and makes a horrible face.
What's that?
Something new.

Jim sleeps in his luxurious bed. The covers knotted aroun him. He hasn't shaven in weeks. His eyes open. He lies staring at the ceiling. After a long moment he gets up. Shuffles toward the bathr in his underwear. He's put on a beer gut.
Jim walks past empty tables. Dials up a coffee and a roll Sits sipping coffee and staring at nothing.
Flashes and blasts of noise. The sounds of Z Factor!
You are victorious!
Jim sits blank-faced in the cockpit.
New high score!
Bored, Jim punches his name into the High Scores board. J All the other high scores say JIM.
Jim walks up to the bar and slides onto a stool.
(in fluent Russian, subtitled) [I'm ready for today's new drink]
(in Russian, subtitled) [I'm afraid I can't help you, my friend.]
Jim thumps his fist on the bar.
(in Russian, subtitled) [Don't argue with me, robot. Give me a new drink.]
There are no new drinks.
What do you mean?
I can make two thousand, seven hundred and thirty-eight cocktails. You've had them all.
The news hits Jim like a death in the family.
There are no new drinks.
On the holographic stage, a sexy LOUNGE SINGER in a slink dress croons a torch song. Jim stands just inches away. He touches her face. The hologram dissolves into static.
Jim drops his hand, restoring the illusion. Closes his ey in an agony of loneliness.

Jim walks past the upscale shops, blind to their displays He comes to a PHOTO BOOTH. The promotional pictures on th side catch his attention: people clowning, smiling, kissi He pulls back the curtain, sits in the booth. The curtain falls. The strobe flashes. A photostrip drops into the tray outside the machine: fou identical shots of Jim staring into the lens without emot
Jim walks numbly along, ignoring the stellar view. He mun potato chips out of a bag. A SWEEPER ROBOT follows him like a dog, collecting crumbs Jim feeds it chips. One for Jim, one for the robot.

Jim enters, still munching chips. The sweeper robot follo Jim stands at the windows. Stares out into the dark. Sigh terrible sigh. Suddenly he's wracked by sobs. Tears welling up. He leans forehead against the glass. Moaning. After a moment he sits down blindly. The whole room begins to slide past him. Confused, Jim looks around. He's accidentally sat down on sweeper robot: it carries him across the room.  TRAVELING SHOT
The robot carries Jim up and down the Celestial Promenade Down an elevator. Past the Concourse Bar. Jim waves. Arthur waves back, speechless.  DECK ONE
The robot heads into a low hatch. Jim ducks to fit throug
ROBOTICS CENTER

A mechanical hive. Here the ship's robots are cleaned, repaired, recharged. Robots bustle everywhere - never colliding, never getting lost. A ballet. Jim's sweeper robot vomits its load of collected dirt int waste chute. Heads into a recharging niche. Jim jumps off. He explores: it's an engineer's fantasia. Jim's eyes show signs of life. But it's a hazardous place, with cranes an platforms, hoses and blowtorches on the move. He exits through another low hatch to find himself in the  HIBERNATION BAY
Thousands of sleepers in their glass tubes. Jim walks amo them, looking at their faces. Suddenly he stops, staring. Inside a pod, a woman stands sleeping. This is AURORA DUNN. A breathtaking beauty.
Who are you? (peers at her data screen) Aurora.
He moves on, browsing people. Stops. Backtracks. He stand front of Aurora, looking in through the glass. He glances at her data screen again.
New York City. Journalist.
A workstation. Jim types "Aurora Dunn" into a search engi It returns a list of New Yorker articles. Some titles:
The New Corporate Overlords Patient or Patent? Genetic Medicine and You Modern Love: Dating the Database Jim moves the articles onto a digital slate.
Jim sits reading one of Aurora's articles. Arthur keeps b
Did you know ninety percent of the businesses in the world are owned by just eight companies?
Is that right?
She's good. She knows her stuff, and she's not afraid of anybody.
Who's that?
Aurora.
Who's Aurora?
A woman. A passenger.

Jim lies asleep, wearing boxer shorts and a full beard. T suite's a wreck. Laundry and dishes litter the floor. His eyes open. He looks at the stars outside. Gropes unde the pillow and pulls out a remote control. Punches a butt The window shades come down, hiding the view.  CORRIDOR

Jim emerges from his room in boxer shorts and slippers. H dragging a blanket. A housekeeping robot, its dustpan quivering in anticipati hovers outside his door. Jim taps the "Do Not Disturb" button on his door panel an walks away. The housekeeping robot squeals in frustration as the door closes over the mess inside.
CAFETERIA
Jim pours milk over a bowl of cereal.  ELEVATOR
Jim descends, the blanket draped over his shoulders like serape. He holds his bowl of cereal in both hands.
Jim stands eating cereal and staring at Aurora. His eyes never stray from her face.
Jim glowers at the bar in his boxers and blanket. The cer bowl on the bar beside him.
I'm not saying the universe is evil. It's just got an ugly sense of humor. It doesn't just crush you. It crushes you ironically.
Things may look dark sometimes...
You get to fly to another planet, but you die on the way. You're completely alone, with the perfect woman right in front of you, just out of reach.
Aurora.
Yes, Aurora! Arthur, I'm falling for her. I've read all her stuff. Sometimes I talk to her and I know exactly what she'd say.
